conversation.content:
[exhausted] You know, I tell people every day—I mean, literally every single day—that grief is like, um, digging a hole. [bitter] You can't rush it, right? Can't force your way through solid earth. [pause] I've buried, what, maybe three thousand people? And honestly, I've got this whole speech down: [warm] "Your loved one is at peace now, the earth will hold them gently," all that. [sarcastic] Real poetic stuff.

[sigh] But here's the thing—when my Sarah died, I just... [trailing off] I couldn't even pick up a shovel for weeks. [quietly] Still can't, actually. Everyone thinks, oh, he must be so wise about death, you know? [laugh] The gravedigger who understands loss! [frustrated] Except I don't—I really, really don't. 

[shaky voice] I give families these perfect words about, er, healing and time and acceptance. [angry] And then I go home to her empty chair and I can't—[pause]—I literally cannot process that she's in the ground I know so well. [very sad] The earth doesn't feel gentle. It feels like, um, like theft. [whispering] Sometimes I think I've buried my ability to grieve along with everyone else's dead. [bitter] Funny how that works, isn't it?
